SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: For a long time there have been fears that China was in the middle of an economic bubble, particularly in the housing sector with a droopy consumer market. It's a fascinating situation with potentially grave implications for the world's second-largest economy. A bubble, in other words, that's in the midst of popping. This looks to a lot of people — especially smug foreigners like ourselves — like a Chinese version of the stock market mania the United States experienced in the 1990s. So what's happening, NSG? What are your thoughts on this?

For a long time, even through China's miraculous multi-decade span of economic growth, Chinese households have been very cautious investors — either holding money in bank accounts or else parking in tangible real estate. Chinese people don't have a lot of experience with stock exchanges, and confidence in the markets was shaken by some so-called "fat finger" trading errors in 2013. But as the Chinese government began to take tentative steps to open up stock markets to foreign investors while simultaneously trying to discourage fevered real estate speculation, retail investors starting pouring in. As retail investors poured in, Chinese stock prices went up. As Chinese stock prices went up, more people decided they wanted to get in on the action. I've always thought this was inevitable. The Chinese economy is based so much on liquid capital and ever-increasing demand that it is so over-extended, that, even with a slight drop in consumption, the whole edifice could crash.
Not suprising when you dump 20% of the GDP into a stimulus package you inevitably cause land, companies, and other entities to be over valued.

It's also a holiday weekend on a day where the stock markets are closed.

It's very hard to predict the result of a sharp decline in stock prices, especially in a country like China where the technocrats are not afraid of taking huge measures in order to bend the market back to their will (they've done plenty of silent 'bailouts' to avoid crises before). I think it's important to note that late 2014 and 2015 saw absolutely insane surges in stock prices alone, practically doubling the value of SHCOMP in under a year, the recent huge falls haven't even erased these gains yet, so it's not like it's erasing price gains that have been building for years and years or even decades.

This gives some perspective, it's just a reversal of very recent gains:
The Shanghai Composite also lost two-thirds of its value in 2007 and the Chinese economy was fine.
Shanghai Composite has gone up 170 points today. PBOC is pledging liquidity. Cap on trading a single Blue Chip Stock raised from 5% to 10%.
Don't think any significant fall from now on. Could be wrong though.
Its certainly the sign of a bubble bursting, but its not particularly damaging. The stock market accounts for just 5% of Chinese household wealth and its still up on last year, even before the rally.
Any further problems with quickly be contained by more stimulus packages.

What is much more worrying is the state of the banking system in China (particularly shadow banking), especially with all those bad loans to things like infrastructure projects. This, coupled with lower growth, and the government effectively becoming a stimulus junkie (it has been continually propping up the economy with injections since 2008), could be more problematic.

Not possible. The Chinese have now tasted the quality of life possible with capitalism (albeit in their case state capitalism), and there's really no going back. The worst case scenario would look more like Thailand, where economic instability has led to multiple military coups and de facto juntas. Though based on China's historical patterns... the sheer size of the country frequently leads to regional power struggles (underpinned by clan aggrandizement), and a destabilized CCP could very well take us all the way back to a 1920s scenario, especially without a popular political figure to unite interest groups. Such would continue, again accord to pattern precedent, until the biggest and most ruthless asshole achieves unity through force. 21st century and the dynastic cycle lives on...
